objtitle.title: A Standing and a Recumbent Figure, Both with Attendant Genii, Possibly for "The Book of Thel"

objdescid.compdate: c. 1789The date is based on stylistic considerations and the possible association of this drawing with Blake's *The Book of Thel*, dated 1789 on its title page.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe pencil letters lower right, "J D F," are the initials of John Deffett Francis, the first recorded owner of the drawing. This inscription may have been written by Francis.
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe pencil letters lower right, "J D F," are the initials of John Deffett Francis, the first recorded owner of the drawing. This inscription may have been written by Francis.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Early history unknown; acquired at an unknown time by John Deffett Francis and given by him to the British Museum in Dec. 1874.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org

desc.objtitle: *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure, Both with Attendant Genii, Possibly for "The Book of Thel"*, object 1 (Butlin 219)

objnote.p: This drawing may be a rejected design for Blake's illuminated book, *The Book of Thel*. The closest association with any of the published designs is with the headpiece to plate 6. If that is indeed the case, then the standing figure on the right might be Thel and the figure floating to the left might be the Cloud. It is difficult to identify the supine figure, the two smaller figures near her head, and the figure holding the hips of the standing figure with any of the other characters in the poem. For another drawing related to plate 6 of *The Book of Thel*, see *Sketch for "The Book of Thel," Plate 6*, Butlin 218 verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Surrounded by vertical lines that suggest trees, a gowned female figure stands on the right side of the composition while a second figure lies on the ground at left. Each is accompanied by two smaller figures, one holding the standing figure's waist and another hovering hear her extended right arm. The pair of smaller figures at lower left are winged. A tree stands far right; other vertical lines may be more tree trunks. This drawing may be a rejected design for Blake's illuminated, *The Book of Thel*. The closest association with any of the published designs is with the headpiece to plate 6. If that is indeed the case, then the standing figure on the right might be Thel and the figure floating to the left might be the Cloud. It is difficult to identify the supine figure, the two smaller figures near her head, and the figure holding the standing figure's hips with any of the other characters in the poem.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female figure stands on the right side of the composition facing forward. She has long, curly hair that appears somewhat flame-like and stands on end in a rightward direction. Her head is turned slightly down and to the left. She frowns noticeably and her eyes may be closed. Her left arm is at her side, her right raised horizontally. Two smaller figures accompany the female figure: one wraps its arms around her hips while the second hovers near her extended right arm, perhaps in an attempt to lead her. This standing figure may be touching the hovering figure to the left and possibly the leg of the figure enbracing her hips. If indeed this drawing is associated with Blake's illuminated book, *The Book of Thel*, this standing figure may be Thel.

A figure, likely a nude female due to the suggestion of breasts, lies supine with head at left in the lower left corner of the design. Her legs are extended and together; her right arm is bent but at her side while her left is extended horizontally away from her body at a 45 degree angle. Her head is bent back and appears to be supported by two smaller figures, both winged, on either side of her head. She may be dead or dying.

One of two smaller figures at right, a nude(?) figure facing away from the viewer wraps its arms around the hips of the standing female figure and extends both legs together (with knees bent?) horizontally to the right. The standing figure may touch or hold this figure's legs with her left hand. The smaller figure may turn its head up to look at the woman it embraces. This figure, perhaps a spirit of some sort, appears to hover in the air.

A small figure flies(?) or hovers in a horizontal position with head at left while touching or holding(?) the standing female figure's extended right arm. This figure may be nude and appears to face forward, though the direction of the head is unclear. It extends one arm horizontally to the left and points downward toward the other figural group, lower left. Its other arm may be bent. Both legs may be extended and possibly bent at the knee. If indeed this drawing is associated with Blake's illuminated book, *The Book of Thel*, this hovering figure may be the Cloud.

Two smaller winged figures, perhaps spirits of putti, accompany the supine figure in the lower left corner of the composition. On the right side of the larger figure's head, the first of the smaller figures sits (perhaps in a squat or crouch?) facing left but turns to look forward. It bends forward and extends its bent left arm to touch or hold the head of the large figure.

Two smaller winged figures, perhaps spirits or putti, accompany the supine figure in the lower left corner of the composition. The figure furthest left faces away from the viewer and bends forward with extended right arm to touch or hold the head of the female figure. Its right leg appears bent forward at the knee and its left extended backward; the figure may fly or hover just above the ground.
Several vertical lines across the width of the composition suggest the trunks and branches of trees. The tree far right is by far the largest.
